awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Structure and resilience of social networks under population turnover
awd_abstract_narration:
Animals live within social networks of individuals that affect each other's lives. However, social networks must change across time; for example, all social networks eventually lose individuals through death or dispersal, and new individuals join social networks through birth and immigration. Thus, the simple and universal processes of birth, death and movement fundamentally shape the structure of social networks at any given time. A major goal of this project is to understand how demography and social behavior interact to affect the development and stability of social networks across time. The project will integrate theoretical models with long-term field research focusing on the social network of flock associations in a wintering migrant bird species, the golden-crowned sparrow. Seasonal social networks in migratory birds allows for the repeated study of the process of network formation with a mix of old and new individuals present in the population each year. As a whole, this project will pose new questions that can shed light on the processes that govern how societies take shape, and the resilience of social structure in the face of constant change, in animal populations and even in human societies. The project will integrate research goals with two different types of educational activities: development of teaching curricula on reproducible research and the recruitment of students of immigrant/refugee background to higher education and science. 

This project proposes a general framework for understanding the temporal dynamics of social networks under population turnover. The model breaks the process into three steps: node loss, node attachment and social integration. Node loss and node attachment dynamics describe the effects of demography, while social integration captures the processes underlying the formation of new flock associations. This model will enable the study of the joint effects of demography, social processes, and fitness consequences of social position on social network structure. The field-based empirical work will explore natural long-term dynamics in social networks spanning multiple generations of a single avian species. Field experiments will be conducted to test the effects of social position on behaviors such as finding novel food sources, as well as, the effects of social relations on dominance interactions.  The educational objectives of this project will make significant contributions towards improving education and enhancing diversity in STEM. This project will enhance the capacity for reproducible research among hundreds of undergraduate and graduate students through development of new curricula. The project will also work to increase recruitment of a significantly overlooked, under-served community, i.e., refugee and immigrant populations in the Midwest. Refugees are hidden sources of diversity in Nebraska and enhancing opportunities for these students will strengthen the U.S. workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
All social networks change membership over time: individuals are lost through death or dispersal, and new individuals join the social network through birth and immigration. Yet we know almost nothing about how this universal process of turnover through demographic processes shapes the structure of social networks, nor do we understand how social networks may or may not be resilient to population turnover. Fluctuations in social structure could have important impacts on ecological and evolutionary processes that arise from social interactions, such as transmission of disease and information or the evolution of social behavior. The proposed project will combine the development of new theory with long-term field research to establish a framework for including turnover dynamics in animal social networks.

We proposed a general framework based on three steps of turnover: node loss, node attachment and social integration. Node loss and node attachment dynamics link to demography: the rates of death, birth, and movement of individuals. In turn, all three components relate to social processes such as the fitness consequences of social position and the behavioral underpinning that determine how social ties are established. We identified understudied processes as particularly important: (i) how the social behavior of an individual is changes (or not) following the loss of social ties, which we term indirect effects of node loss, and (ii) the social behavior of new recruits or immigrants to the population, which we term social integration. This framework for understanding how demographic processes affect animal social networks effectively links population ecology and life history theory to the study of social evolution.

The project has contributed to the broadening scope of animal social network studies through incorporation of multiple sources of empirical data from natural populations, including cooperatively breeding bird species, mixed-species flocks, and non-breeding social systems. This project has expanded our ability to construct social networks from a variety of data collection methods, within and across species. Across all of these systems, some common theme strikes out: social interactions in birds are dynamic with respect to both environment and long-term relationships, and understanding the role of social relationships across individuals’ lifetimes can drive the responses of population to perturbations.

Continued long-term empirical research on the social network of migrant birds (golden-crowned sparrow, Zonotrichia atricapilla) was particularly important, as this has enabled the repeated study of the process of network assembly with a mix of old and new individuals each year. We found that this social network is seasonal, with little evidence of birds in the same flocks continuing associations during the breeding season. Our studies show that social behavior among birds that are familiar with each other through repeated, stable social associations in flocks are different than social behavior among birds that are unfamiliar with each other. Importantly, we demonstrate that the loss of social partners across years leads to weakening of otherwise strong spatial fidelity to winter home ranges. Moreover, we show that the interplay between the process of social integration of new recruits and the importance of long-term social relationships jointly explains how the social network changes across years along with turnover of the population.

The project integrated research with educational and Broader Impacts activities, including (1) development of curricula on reproducible research at the undergraduate and graduate level, and (2) recruitment of students of immigrant/refugee background to higher education and science, and (3) training students for a new STEM workforce. Reproducible research methods were built into undergraduate labs for the large-enrollment ecology and evolution course, and they became a central component of graduate courses in R and network analysis as well as a conference short course. The project also succeeded in supporting recruitment of immigrant/refugee backgrounds as well as other historically marginalized groups, both at the undergraduate and graduate level. The project expanded the capacity to train both undergraduate and graduate students for a new STEM workforce through REU and INTERN supplemental funding.
